awd_titl_txt: Targeted Infusion Project: Inspiring, Engaging and Retaining Underrepresented Students in Computing Research and the Emerging Field of Data Science
awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) through Targeted Infusion Projects supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue STEM graduate programs and/or careers. This project at Howard University intends is to introduce undergraduate students to data science approaches and to enhance conceptual knowledge through applied learning activities. Proposed activities which include the hosting of data science workshops and conferences will further support student learning and increase student competitiveness for graduate studies and/or future employment opportunities.

The objective of this proposed work is to infuse data science into the curriculum which will enable students under the leadership of the course instructor to apply their skills to the exploration of scientific questions that were previously inaccessible using traditional approaches. For example, students will use High Performance Computing to examine levels of archaic human ancestry that have been inferred to be present in the genomes of contemporary populations. The project will support the training of over 600 minority undergraduate students in cutting-edge methods in data science throughout the Biology curriculum, increasing their competitiveness for graduate studies and/or future employability in a variety of settings, including in biomedical and environmental sciences, research education, and public service.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
The project aimed to introduce students to data science approaches and enhance their conceptual knowledge through applied learning activities. Recognizing the growing importance of data analysis across various fields, this initiative sought to equip undergraduate students with the skills necessary for effective data analysis. Additionally, the project specifically addressed the underrepresentation of women and minorities (Hispanic/Latino and African American) in data science education at the undergraduate level.

Key Actions

  1. Acquisition of New Software and Hardware:
    • The project procured essential technology, including local computers and a High-Performance Computing node, to support course-based activities within the Department of Biology at Howard University. This infrastructure enabled students to engage in data science-related tasks and analyses.
  2. Integration of Data Science into Core Biology Courses:
    • Fundamental data science techniques were incorporated into existing Biology courses, particularly General Biology 101 and 102 at Howard University. This integration helped students develop a foundational understanding of data science concepts and their applications in biology.
  3. Development of Data Science Modules for Upper-Year Electives:
    • Newly developed data science modules were created for upper-year Biology elective courses. These project-based activities provided students with firsthand experience in using data science methods to analyze biological data and make meaningful interpretations.
  4. Enhancement of Quantitative and Analytical Skills:
    • Through project-based activities in upper-year Biology elective courses, the project sought to enhance students' quantitative and analytical skills. By engaging with real-world datasets and applying data science techniques, students effectively analyzed and interpreted complex biological data.
  5. Improvement of Scientific Literacy and Communication Skills:
    • Emphasizing scientific literacy and communication, the project offered opportunities for students to communicate their findings, present analyses, and engage in scientific discourse through the newly developed project-based activities and modules.

Long-Term Impacts

  1. Increasing Interest and Learning in STEM Among Underrepresented Students:
    • By integrating data science into biology education at Howard University, the project aimed to attract and engage underrepresented students in STEM fields, particularly women and minorities, thereby addressing the existing representation deficiency in data science education.
  2. Preparation for Graduate and Professional Programs:
    • The project equipped undergraduate students with the necessary skills and knowledge for success in rigorous graduate and professional programs. Enhanced data science and analytical skills will better prepare students for advanced studies and careers that require proficiency in data analysis.
  3. Establishing Collaborative Partnerships:
    • The project fostered collaborative partnerships with other scientists and STEM educators. By disseminating outcomes at local and national conferences, the project intends to share its findings, learn from other institutions, and pool expertise to further enhance data science education.

Conclusion

Overall, the project aimed to bridge the gap in data science education, particularly for underrepresented groups, by integrating data science approaches into biology courses, enhancing students' skills and knowledge, and fostering collaborations and partnerships within the scientific community.

 

 


Last Modified: 08/31/2024
Modified by: Clarence M Lee
